awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Formation and Stability of Eutectic Nanostructures in Laser-Irradiated Particle Suspensions
awd_abstract_narration:
Powder metallurgy, in which complex parts are made by fusing together a metal powder, has a large economic footprint in the USA. This footprint will only grow as additive manufacturing (AM) techniques become more pervasive. A pressing concern with AM is that the parts produced often have worse mechanical properties than parts produced from forging or machining. The goal of this collaborative project is to develop new approaches to create a nanoscale physical structure within powder particles in order to improve mechanical properties (strength and thermal conductivity) of final parts. To accomplish this, this research will use lasers to melt different metal and ceramic alloys that have a special chemical composition, known as a eutectic, which produces an internal sheet-like structure. By lasing the powders while they are in a fluid that extracts heat quickly, the eutectic structure can be preserved when the particle solidifies. This work will suspend the powder particles in liquid and solid media that can remove heat, but these media must not react, boil, or obscure the laser. Experiments will be combined with modeling to understand the removal of heat, and to simulate how the internal structure forms within indivdual spherical particles under these conditions. Success in this research would enable a new class of tailored materials to be used in sintering and additive manufacturing to rapidly manufacture complex pieces with improved technical properties. This will have significant direct benefits for the aerospace, automotive, medical products, and defense industries. In addition, the PIs have a good history of recruiting underrepresented minority students in their research, and this effort will continue.

Pulsed laser melting and cooling in certain fluids can provide very fast solidification rates to form nanoscale eutectic structures. Unfortunately, in materials with high optical absorption, lasers with nanosecond pulse widths only melt the near-surface region and cannot be considered true bulk processing techniques. This research will circumvent this limitation by using laser irradiation of eutectic alloys in powder form. Most investigations of eutectic solidification in discrete particles have used molten droplets formed by atomization, where heat extraction from the particle into a surrounding gas is inefficient. Although rapid eutectic solidification still occurs, atomization results in highly heterogeneous internal microstructures, which are undesirable with respect to many technical properties. This research will employ particles suspended in liquid or solid media that can extract heat much more efficiently following pulsed laser melting. The suspensions will be volume-restricted such that boiling of the media in contact with the molten particles is suppressed, thereby maintaining effective heat dissipation. In addition, by controlling the laser power and number of pulses, it is possible to partially melt a particle if desired. The experiments will examine these processes in metallic, semiconducting and metal-oxide alloy powders. The dynamic rapid solidification process in bulk and three-dimensional particles will be simulated in detail using the phase field modeling approach. The stability of the nanoscale eutectic structure during spark plasma sintering of the produced particulate material will also be examined.The Broader Impacts of this research include the new processing approaches that create tailored microstructures in feedstock materials for use in sintering and additive manufacturing that will yield improved mechanical and electrical properties in rapidly-manufactured components. This will have significant direct benefits for the aerospace, automotive, medical products, and defense industries.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia

por.por_cntn:
Additive manufacturing directly builds complex metal parts using a powerful focused laser beam to locally melt metal powders, in the right place and at the right time. A layer of powder is laid down onto a substrate, then the laser is scanned in a pattern that melts the powder into a solid form, thereby defining the initial layer of the build. Unused powder is removed, a new layer of powder gets laid down, and the process repeats until the part is completely formed, with minimal waste since unused powder gets recycled. Melting/solidification processes are crucial to the properties of the built part, and the final strength depends on the laser scanning conditions and the nature of the metallic powder. Understanding the underlying science is really important - a printed part must be as reliable and perform at least as well as the part built by more traditional methods.

Intellectual Merit:

This project investigated additive manufacturing by making novel use of eutectic alloys of aluminum and copper to probe the additive melting+solidification process.  A eutectic alloy is a combination of two metals that has a melting point lower than either pure metal.  But what is truly special is that when a eutectic alloy solidifies, it forms two different phases (metallic structures) that arrange themselves in thin, parallel sheets called lamellae. These sheets repeat side-by-side everywhere, and the thickness of the sheets is controlled only by how fast the laser beam is scanned. The arrangement and spacing of the lamellae tells researchers a great deal about how the solidification proceeded in the complex environment of an additive build.

One major part of this project examined the starting powder materials, which are critical building blocks for the final printed components.  A pre-alloyed metallic powder was used - each particle of the powder was already at the correct ratio of Al:Cu for the eutectic. These particles were examined before and after they were melted, and the eutectic provided an obvious indication of which particles melted, see Figure 1. Surprisingly, the particles often melted without joining or spreading out, because they are contained inside a tough shell of aluminum oxide, only 100 atoms thick. However, when the molten metal inside the initially spherical shell of oxide solidified, it heavily deformed the oxide shell, forming particles with large craters and rifts.

A serious limitation to additive manufacturing is that pre-alloyed powders of arbitrary compositions are often unavailable. This project investigated using readily-available pure metal powders instead - first mixing the dry powders, then forming the alloy by achieving intimate atomic mixing within the melt as the build was happening. The eutectic structure gives an easily-seen signal for when the real-time alloying was insufficient, see Figure 2. The project showed that real-time alloying can be used, but it's critical to select and characterize proper starting powders, and select appropriate laser conditions to ensure full mixing.

In the eutectic Al-Cu builds investigated here, research showed that the expected lamellar spacing behavior was controllable directly by the laser scan speed. Then it was shown that the mechanical strength of the build increased as the lamellar plates got narrower. This continues until the lamellar structure breaks down at high scan speeds, whereupon strengthening is lost, see Figure 3. This research also showed that the many internal boundaries between adjacent laser scans, which locally destroy the lamellar structure, are weak points.

The project also examined fundamental instabilities in lamellar eutectic growth by using Al-Cu thin films that provide a much simpler geometry for easier measurement and understanding. Instabilities that create wavy or chaotic lamellar structure during solidification are known to occur when solidification happens too fast. This investigation revealed the unexpected result that instabilities occurred as the solidification velocity was reduced, see Figure 4. This owes to the inherent nature of Al-Cu eutectics, and this nature is shared by other eutectic alloys, so it will be important in those systems as well.

Broader Impacts:

By exploiting eutectic solidification behavior, this project showed that changes in powder shape occur after melting.  If this powder gets recycled, it will not behave as well in subsequent use, leading to defects in the part.  Real-time alloying of elemental powders could make additive manufacturing a more generally applied technique encompassing a wider variety of metals. The ability to control eutectic lengthscales is important since it allows materials designers to consider how to best additively manufacture their components for optimal properties.

  Funding from the National Science Foundation provided excellent hands-on research training to two graduate students, and three undergraduate students. The project Principal Investigators were able, with the credibility afforded by the NSF grant, to continue performing science outreach in schools around central Virginia, touching 800-1000 lives each year prior to the pandemic, in order to make science and engineering more accessible to children and families.


Last Modified: 03/24/2022
Modified by: J. A Floro

Images (1 of )
  • Al-Cu and pure Al powders before (left) and after (right) laser irradiation. The melted particles developed craters and rifts. The melted Al-Cu particles show a distinct change in the dark/light lamellar structure that indicate melting happened.
    Jonathan Skelton
    Public Domain
    J. A Floro
    Figure 1
  • Four combinations of powder sizes were investigated for real-time alloying (a-d). These have been mixed at the eutectic composition. Panel (e) shows an additive build that did not mix well � the dark and light regions are not at the proper eutectic composition. Panel (f) is magnified view of (e).
    Jonathan Skelton
    Public Domain
    J. A Floro
    Figure 2
  • Figure 3. The graph shows the mechanical hardness (Vickers microhardness) plotted against the laser scan velocity used to build the part. Below the graphs are the images of the corresponding structure, all at the same magnification. Beyond (e), the eutectic lamellar structure breaks down.
    Jonathan Skelton
    Public Domain
    J. A Floro
    Figure 3
  • Figure 4. (a) A 200 nm thick eutectic Al-Cu film undergoing stable solidification. The dark and light stripes are the lamellae. (b) Another Al-Cu film with about 3 atomic percent more aluminum. Solidification is now undergoing significant instability, creating �chaotic� lamellar structure.
    Eli Sullivan
    Public Domain
    J. A Floro
    Figure 4
